conclusion: We are tasked with finding the magnitude of the external force F applied to slider B, given that both sliders are on the verge of not sliding upwards on the inclined plane.
Two sliders A and B are connected by a light rope on an inclined plane with an angle of 37 degrees. A horizontal force F is applied to slider B.

The coefficient of kinetic friction between the sliders and the inclined plane is 0.5, and the maximum static friction is equal to the kinetic friction. Gravitational acceleration is g, and sin(37°) = 0.6.
Slider A is positioned lower on the incline, and slider B is positioned higher. The rope connecting them is taut.
The forces acting on slider A include gravitational force, normal force, frictional force, and tension in the rope.
The gravitational force on slider A can be decomposed into components: parallel to the incline (mg sin θ) and perpendicular to the incline (mg cos θ).
The frictional force on slider A is f_A = μN_A, where N_A = mg cos θ.
The tension in the rope for slider A is T = mg sin θ + μ(mg cos θ).
The forces acting on slider B include gravitational force, normal force, frictional force, tension in the rope, and the external force F.
The gravitational force on slider B can be decomposed into components: parallel to the incline (mg sin θ) and perpendicular to the incline (mg cos θ).
The frictional force on slider B is f_B = μN_B, where N_B = mg cos θ.
The component of the external force F along the incline is F_parallel = F cos θ.
The force balance equation for slider B along the incline is F cos θ - T - mg sin θ - μ(mg cos θ) = 0.
Rearranging the force balance equation for slider B gives F cos θ = T + mg sin θ + μ(mg cos θ).
Substitute T = mg(sin θ + μ cos θ) from slider A into the equation for slider B: F cos θ = mg(sin θ + μ cos θ) + mg sin θ + μ(mg cos θ).
Simplify the equation to F cos θ = mg(2 sin θ + 2 μ cos θ).
Divide both sides by cos θ to solve for F: F = mg(2 sin θ + 2 μ cos θ) / cos θ.
